citation.article-title: Tetragenococcus koreensis sp. nov., a novel rhamnolipid-producing bacterium
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Tetragenococcus koreensis sp. nov.
Tetragenococcus koreensis (ko.re.en′sis. N.L. masc. adj. koreensis pertaining to Korea, the origin of the sample of the traditional food, kimchi, from which the type strain was isolated).
Cells are non-motile, non-spore-forming cocci (approx. 1 μm in length).
Grows on trypticase soy agar at 30 °C aerobically and in an anaerobic jar, but does not grow on R2A agar, nutrient agar or MacConkey agar at 30 °C under either aerobic or anaerobic conditions.
Fatty acid profile largely composed of C18 : 1ω7c (33·8 %), C19 : 0 cyclo ω8c (26·8 %) and C16 : 0 (22·4 %).
Growth occurs at 15–30 °C on GYP/sodium acetate/mineral salts agar but not at temperatures of 4 °C or above 37 °C.
Growth occurs at NaCl concentrations in the range 0–8 % (w/v).
The NaCl concentration for best growth is 2–5 % (w/v).
Demonstrates homofermentative production of lactic acid.
The peptidoglycan type is A4α l-lys–d-Asp.
Nitrate is not reduced to nitrite or nitrogen gas.
The G+C content of the DNA is 38·3 mol%. β-Glucosidase- and β-galactosidase-positive, but protein is not hydrolysed.
Characterized by the production of rhamnolipid biosurfactant.
Isolated from the traditional Korean food kimchi in Daejeon, South Korea.
